sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using block matrices:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 6 \\ 3\end{pmatrix}$$ 

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} p \\ q \\ r \end{pmatrix} +\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \\ 4 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}$$
message_2:
To solve the given systems of linear equations, we first find the inverse of the coefficient matrices and then multiply it with the constant matrices to get the solutions.

For the first system of equations:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 6 \\ 3\end{pmatrix}$$

Find the inverse of the coefficient matrix:

$$A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 4 \\ 5 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}^{-1} = \frac{1}{11} \begin{pmatrix} -7 & 2 & 2 \\ 5 & 2 & -4 \\ 15 & 6 & -6 \end{pmatrix}$$

Now, multiply the inverse with the constant matrix:

$$\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = A^{-1}b = \frac{1}{11} \begin{pmatrix} -7 & 2 & 2 \\ 5 & 2 & -4 \\ 15 & 6 & -6 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 6 \\ 3\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}$$

So, the solution for the first system is x = 1, y = 2, and z = -1.

For the second system of equations:

$$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} p \\ q \\ r \end{pmatrix} +\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -3 \\ 4 \\ 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \\ 1\end{pmatrix}$$

Since the coefficient matrix is not a square matrix, we cannot find its inverse directly. Instead, we can use the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse to find an approximate solution. Let's denote the pseudoinverse as $A^+$:

$$A^+ = \left(\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^T \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}\right)^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}^T$$

$$A^+ = \begin{pmatrix} 0.25 & 0.25 & 0.25 \\ 0.25 & -0.25 & 0.25 \\ 0.25 & 0.25 & -0.25 \end{pmatrix}$$

Now, we can find the approximate solution by multiplying the pseudoinverse with the difference between the constant matrices:

$$\begin{pmatrix} p \\ q \\ r \end{pmatrix} = A^+ (c - d) = \begin{pmatrix} 0.25 & 0.25 & 0.25 \\ 0.25 & -0.25 & 0.25 \\ 0.25 & 0.25 & -0.25 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -2 \\ 3 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -0.25 \\ 0.75 \\ -0.25 \end{pmatrix}$$

So, the approximate solution for the second system is p = -0.25, q = 0.75, and r = -0.25.
